It could also expose an important clue to the rest of the word, thereby leading to further payment for each correct letter and also the possibility of a word bonus.

"Or alternatively, the turn could be sold to another player who has offered a large cash sum to take it over.

"Be very careful... some of the words are not as obvious as they appear!"
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Betting and Bluffing, Pattern Recognition

name: Burke's Law
description:
Burke's Law game by Transogram from 1963. Based on the hit ABC show starring Gene Barry.

The board shows the outline of two large houses - a country house and a city house. Inside each house are squares that are the possible rooms where the murder could have occurred.

There are three possible murder weapons - gun, knife or poison, and four tokens for each type.

There are 12 murder victims tokens - male or female under blankets that were each one of six different colors. The feet sticking out from under the blanket indicate the gender - small feet in little black heels for the females; large black dress shoes for the males.

There were 12 murderer tokens - people of different dress and hair colors - 6 possible clothing colors, 6 possible hair colors, two genders.

There were 7 types of cards with 6 in each - hair color, clothing color, gender, murder weapon, victim gender, victim blanket color, and location (country or city).

As players take turns, the murder rooms will gradually become populated with murders, victims and weapons - one of each in each room, and the players hands will gradually get one of each card type. The goal is to get the cards in your hand to exactly match one of the murder rooms. The first person to do so wins.

When you roll the number for a card type you *already* have in your hand, you get to pick up all the cards of that type still in the pile, look at all of them, and exchange any one of them for the one in your hand, if you want to do so.

name: Whale Shogi
description: Whale Shogi was created by R. Wayne Schmittberger, the former editor of Games magazine. It is played on a 6x6 board, and the pieces are all named after sea mammals. Normal Shogi drop rules apply. The porpoise is the only piece that promotes. If the porpoise is captured, it must be promoted to a killer whale when it is dropped back on the board.

name: NanoBlanks
description:
From the official product page on the Looney Labs website;

NanoBlanks are packets of do-it-yourself expansion cards for Nanofictionary (much like Fluxx Blanxx are for Fluxx). Each pack contains 10 semi-blank cards for you to be creative with: 4 Characters, 2 Settings, 2 Problems, and 2 Resolutions. Buy NanoBlanks!

Each packet of NanoBlanks also includes:

The Juror Award: Now your jurors can have a real card to use when giving away their 2 points!

The Wild Idea Action: As you begin expanding your Nanofictionary deck with your own ideas, you'll need extra Action cards to keep the balance right.

The Aquarius Wildcard: This long-awaited card is for use in your Aquarius deck. It counts as one panel of all 5 elements at all times.

(Description quoted with permission from Looney Labs.)
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Party Game

name: Anteel
description:
Anteel is a rules-light but tactically serious space wargame, which is totally diceless. In fact, there are no randomizers of any kind, resulting in a game that is all about strategy, rather than luck. There is record keeping, but it's limited to the damage each ship has taken, and convenient fleet control sheets are provided. The rules are easy to master, but to play well, you'll have to be planning several moves in advance, much like in Chess or other classic strategy games.

Gameplay is quick but nail-biting as you watch to see what plans your opponent will undo with an unexpected move.
categories: Miniatures, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Whatchamacallit Word Game
description:
A new concept in word games with the great advantage of involving all the players in the fun of the game all of the time. The game can be played by the whole family & by any number of players.

The game centres around the planners or plans. These are the 'Crosswords' made up by all the players before the play actually begins. These planners are filled out by each player in crossword fashion on a particular theme or subject eg. Film Stars, The Sea, Sport etc & the rest of the players have to find the words in these plans - the player with the most points being the winner.

A game concept that can grow & even use tiles from other word games !
publishers: Crown & Andrews Ltd., Peter Pan Playthings

name: The Ultimate Family Quiz Kit
description:
Part of the Ultimate Quiz Kits series.
The ultimate family quiz—over 2,000 questions for every level, from beginner to buff.

Contains everything required for a fun quiz at home, at work or in the pub. The CD-ROM allows you to print off questions to suit your own friends and family.

This title contains: 6 pens, question and answer CD-ROM, joker cards, score boards, answers pad, score chart, quiz cards

Box size: 340mm x 250mm x 50mm
Book size: 297mm x 210mm
124 pp quiz book
CD-Rom
Wipe-clean score boards
Answer pad and pens
Score chart

name: Adugo
description:
Game created by the Brazilian Indians from Bororo tribe, on Pantanal region. Originally the board was designed on the dust, and pieces were little stones.

One "Jaguar" (Panthera onca) must capture 5 of the 14 dogs. The dogs must trap the "jaguar". The "jaguar" moves like the checkers pieces and "jump" the dogs to capture them. The dogs move like the king from chess.

name: Corregidor: Fall of a Fortress -1942/1945
description:
Corregidor is a simulation of the two battles fought for Corregidor and the fortefied islands at the entrance to Manila Bay during World War II. The first battles began with the bombing of the island in ealry 1942 and ended in May of that year with it's surrender.
After General Douglas MacArthur's return to the Philippines, Corregidor once again became a target of invasion, both to avenge the loss three years before and to clear the mouth of Manila Bay to Allied shipping.
Corregidor: Fall of a Fortress 1942/1945, includes two games. The first game recreates the Japanese bombardment and invasion in 1942 and the second simulates the American airborne invasion and reconquest in 1945.


EXTENDED GAME DESCRIPTION:

CORREGIDOR is played in successive game turns composed of alternate player turns during which the phasing player maneuvers his units and resolves combat in sequence. Turns consist of the Administrative Phases (reinforcement arrival, disruption removal, Fired marker removal), the Air Attack Phase (which includes airborne assault), first Player Turn (AA fire, bombardment, invasion, ground movement, and combat), and then the second Player Turn.

Some detail features of the game are tracking Japanese landing craft losses, American communications disruption, U.S. air and naval support points, unit disruption levels, and which artillery units have fired.

The six hexes adjacent to an undisrupted land unit constitute that unit’s Zone of Control. Disrupted land units DO NOT have ZOCs, and therefore judicious use of support to disrupt enemy units allows the attacker to infiltrate through weak positions and to launch flanking attacks against defending units. This is critical because defending units are doubled and sometimes tripled by the rugged and the unique features on the maps, such as rough terrain, cliffs, elevation changes, tunnels, towns, and coast defense artillery emplacements.

In the 1942 scenarios, there is a cat-and-mouse game which develops between the Japanese artillery and air units versus the American artillery and anti-aircraft defenses. Aircraft need to designate the altitude at which they conduct bombing – the lower the attack level the more accurate the bombing, but also the more accurate the AA fire. Similarly, artillery which fires is more vulnerable to counter-battery fire and so making a bombardment attack must be weighed against the possibility of return fire.

In 1945, in addition to banzai options, the Japanese have the option to make suicide demolitions, which destroy the attacking unit but also damage adjacent units. There is a mechanism to occasionally compel such attacks, which not only forces some historicity but it also models the uncoordinated local Japanese command structure in 1945.

Some optional rules included:

Spike Rule - U.S. Batteries must be spiked when Japanese units come within two hexes to prevent them from being captured in usable condition. They may not be voluntarily destroyed until after a Japanese unit has landed on their island. Flip the battery over after the following U.S. Bombardment Phase. The unit may then move and fight normally.

Restored Batteries - Roll one die on the turn of the American invasion in 1945 for the surviving former U.S. batteries:
1 – Battery may fire normally.
2 – Battery sabotaged by POWs, gun crew fights as infantry.
3-6 – Battery was never manned; remove from map.

Additional U.S. Batteries - Three 240mm howitzer batteries which were to be installed in 1922 actually arrive. One battery is deployed anywhere on Fort Frank, one on Fort Hughes, and one on Fort Mills (Corregidor).

Philippine Division Transferred - The 31st, 45th, and 57th Regiments are transferred to Corregidor prior to the fall of Bataan. Add them to the available U.S. forces in Scenario 11.1. Due to the effects of fighting on Bataan, plus short rations and disease, these units are deployed at reduced strength. As an additional option, they may be deployed at full strength to simulate these units being in better condition historically.

Itagaki Rule - Japanese defense commander Capt. Itagaki did not believe an airborne assault could be made on Corregidor. He was killed on Topside during the initial paradrop, while waiting to observe the amphibious assault for which he had prepared. Additionally, his central communications station was overrun very quickly by the paratroops. In this rule, he is killed and no Japanese unit may move until the first night turn.

U.S. Roving Batteries - During the campaign for Bataan and Corregidor, the U.S. created a number of “roving batteries” of 155mm guns by removing them from their emplacements and mounting them such that they could be moved about Corregidor.

U.S. Searchlights - The U.S. had several searchlight batteries on the Fortified Islands. This option forces the Japanese to actually expend the effort to destroy them and if they are not, they provide some advantage to the U.S. Player.

If a Japanese invasion or evacuation is occurring in a night turn and there is an active U.S. searchlight unit on the map, the U.S. Player receives a +2 die modifier (cumulative with any other DRMs) when firing on Japanese units in water hexes.

If a Japanese air bombardment is conducted at night, U.S. Anti-aircraft fire receives an additional +1 modifier to any other DRMs which apply; Japanese Bombardment rolls receive an additional -1 modifier to any other DRMs which apply.

Battery Way - Battery Way did not have a crew and was not operational until April 28. The U.S. might have activated this battery sooner. Roll at the beginning of the 0300 daily turn. The battery is active at full strength on a roll of 2 or 12. The battery becomes active automatically on Turn 65 if not activated sooner.


Game scale
Unit size: Generally artillery batteries and infantry platoons, with some company- and section-size units. Some individual naval units are depicted; air units are generally three aircraft per step.

Game turn: Movement and combat on the Fortified Islands maps is in three-hour turns in 1942, and two-hour daylight turns in 1945, with night turns representing five hours each. There are also daily turns to keep track of reinforcements as well as to frame the complete campaigns. By mutual agreement, players may skip any daily or hourly turn in which neither player plans to execute any movement, combat, or bombardment.

Hex scale: The scale of the Fortified Islands map is roughly 250 yards per hex; the scale of the Bataan map is roughly 1.25 miles per hex.

name: Tatchanka!
description:
Tatchanka!
Russian Civil War Campaigns in the Ukraine, 1919

Tatchanka depicts the 1919 campaigns in Central and Eastern Ukraine. Two or three players control the opposing armies in any of four scenarios. The game shows central and eastern Ukraine at 32 kilometers/20 miles per hex and 7-8 days per turn, and the armies involved at about 2,000 combat troops per unit, with additional logistical bases, armored trains, river gunboats, and arms stockpiles.

The design has been trimmed to focus on two key campaigns. *Fall of the Directory* shows the three-sided conflict at the end of 1918 and the first few months of 1919, where the Bolsheviks overthrew the Directory. *Revolt Against the Volunteer Army* shows the decisive campaigns in the last few months of 1919 and the beginning of 1920. *The Road to Freedom?* and *The Bolshevik Advance* present shorter parts of *Revolt.* *The Road to Freedom?* shows the Makhnovist campaign toward their home ground and into the Volunteer Army's rear areas, and the renewed uprising. *The Bolshevik Advance* shows the Volunteer Army retreating onto the map, and the Red Army chasing after them, with all sides scrambling to control key areas.

These scenarios represent campaigns which could have changed the course of the Ukrainian Civil War. In *Fall of the Directory,* the Directory could have defeated the Bolsheviks and quite possibly have retained independence. In *Revolt Against the Volunteer Army,* the Makhnovists could have won a stronger position and quite possibly have gained autonomy.

Note: The early drafts used larger hexes, larger units, and a smaller map than the current design. The design notes sometimes refer to "Revolt Against the Volunteer Army" as "Makhno's Return."

name: Go Diamond!
description:
From the rules sheet:
The object of Go Diamond is to be the first person to accomplish and maintain all of the following:
Completely fill in the Organization Chart that each player has with People Chips.
Reach the 7500 level on the Go Diamond ladder with second pawn.
Acquire and keep one Dream Card from each of the three separate color-coded Dream categories.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Election '68
description: Election '68 (CreaTek, 1967) does an excellent job of featuring the early candidates in caricature form on cards, and shows the probable front runners for each party on the cover: Richard Nixon for the Republicans; Robert Kennedy for the Democrats with Lyndon Johnson who had decided to not seek re-election "presiding" over both.

name: 1 on 1 Adventure Gamebooks: The Doomsday Device
description: The eighth game in the series of 1 on 1 Adventure Gamebooks pits Marvel Comics' Fantastic Four against Dr. Doom.

name: Ordeal Before Shuri
description:
From the front cover:

Ordeal Before Shuri provides eight individual scenarios and a new campaign game depicting the assault of the American 96th and 27th Divisions against the Japanese garrison on Okinawa. You'll also receive new rules for additional weaponry, such as the Japanese 330mm 'Spigot' mortar, VT Fuses, and 4.5 inch Air to Ground Rockets, plus extensive play aids and charts. The terrain is inhospitable as any Pacific battlefield faced by American soldiers during the Second World War and each individual terrain feature is faithfully depicted on the game map. Ordeal Before Shuri is the beginning of a three-game series of modules depicting the Battle of Okinawa.

Another Squads & Leaders compatible module from Critical Hit!
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Ordet er ditt
description: A word game where the players collect letters to make as long words as possible. It is even possible get imaginary words approved by the other players if you can explain them and find a reasonable meaning.

name: Mayberry-opoly
description:
In October 1960, The Andy Griffith Show made its television debut—and, to the delight of millions worldwide, the show has been on the air ever since! Young and old alike love Mayberry’s cast of characters, timeless humor and the values the show promotes.

Mayberry-Opoly is a game celebrating this classic television show. Players buy favorite Mayberry properties, then increase their property value by collecting Bait Shops and trading them for a Big Fish. Who knows, you may win a blue ribbon for your homemade pickles, sell some jars of Miracle Salve, find your windows broken by Ernest T. Bass, or get arrested by Deputy Barney Fife!

Whether you are relaxing at the fishin’ hole or planning your escape from cell #2, Mayberry-Opoly is loaded with twists that will have everyone laughing and reminiscing about America’s favorite small town.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Tenet
description:
Tenet is the third game from a pentalogy of abstract games based in the Latin magic square.





S

A

T

O

R



A

R

E

P

O



T

E

N

E

T



O

P

E

R

A



R

O

T

A

S

name: Tanagra
description:
This abstract game consists of equilateral triangular tiles. During the initial setup, each tile must touch at least one other triangle already placed on the table, and then one of the players pawns is placed on the center of the triangle tile. The second phase involves pawn displacement and hunting. The object of the game is to capture all the pawns of the player on your left or to insulate them by moving or eliminating the tiles.

The playing time has been listed as either 30 or 60 minutes. This may depend upon the number of players.

Awards:

1990 - Concours International de Créateurs de Jeux de Société de Boulogne-Billancourt Winner of the Golden goblet.

name: Wargaming World War Two
description:
From the rear cover of the book:

In this book Stuart Asquith, editor of Practical Wargamer magazine and contributing editor to Military Modelling magazine, provides a comprehensive guide to wargaming the World War Two period.

He begins by outlining the main events of the 1939-1945 conflict, year by year, and moves on to analyse the war by considering separately the three services - land, sea and air. He discusses each in terms of the background information, organisational details, weaponry and equipment of the major combatant nations suggesting appropriate wargaming rules and scenarios.
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: The Great Black Swamp
description: 1795 Indian War Game. Be the first to reach Ft. Greenville, sign the Peace Treaty, and return to Ft. Defiance. You might be stopping at Ft. Miamis, Ft. Adams, Ft. Recovery or Ft. Wayne along your journey.
publishers: Junior Achievement Company of Defiance, Ohio

name: Cleave
description:
Cleave can be played on a checker board. Each player starts with 16 soldiers 8 on each of the back ranks and 8 on the third ranks. All soldiers move like chess rooks. There are two ways to capture the opponents soldiers, by custodian and by intervention. Custodian capturing is accomplished by ending one of your soldiers movement next to an opponent's while having one of your own on the opposite side as well. To capture by intervention you move one of your soldiers directly between two opposing soldiers and then capture both soldiers on each side. The edge of the board can be used to complete any line of three, capturing an opponent piece near the edge by either custodian or intervention. The game is played until one opponent has no legal moves, which he then loses. A player also loses if he is reduced to two or less soldiers.

Hosted for online play by SuperDuperGames.ORG, where it is known as "Mak-Yek".

name: Screech
description:
Glow-in-the-Dark Concentration.

Screech uses a plastic owl that tells you the type of "insect" to find by showing the insect in its eyes. Players search through cards and place the cards in the owl to determine if they have the right card. (The owl has a flashlight inside the unit to flash the image on the cards to make them glow in the dark).

name: To the Banners:  Rules for Pike & Shot 1500-1700
description:
These rules are designed for fast play during an era of European land warfare across two centuries. They strive for simplicity while providing a feeling for the nature of battle during this time.

The rules are tuned to enable simulation of smaller scale actions rather than the large-scale battles that are more commonly the focus of miniatures rules but were more infrequent than the types of actions (raids, ambushes, assaults and patrols) these rules are suitable for.

Given this scale of focus, the rules are designed for play with 25mm figures but may be easily re-scaled for 15mm. Rather than offer army lists as such, these rules instead provide lists of characteristics of various unit types (e.g., gendarmes, landsknechts, various nationalities of shot and pike) by period: Tudor Wars, Italian Wars, Thirty Years War, English Civil Wars, and Louis XIV. Along with these lists, there is a system for generating armies based on unit cost. A representative scenario is provided for each of the five periods of the lists.
categories: Book, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: The Leeds United Football Game
description: This is a soccer game using the team and players of Leeds United. The game focuses on the placement of players on the board and uses a combination of die rolling and card drawing to establish player movement and goal scoring. In addition to winning matches, players also focus on accumulating the largest amount of money.

name: Celebrity Piggy
description:
Here's a fast-moving fun game for people of all ages. It's a great party game because any number of people can play. Or you can challenge just one person to a duel with the dice. In the place of 1's on the dice are smiling pigs.

Everybody antes one chip into the pot. You roll the dice as many times as you want to earn 100 points, but rolling a piggy ends your turn and rolling two piggies takes away all the points accumulated up to that point in the game (at which point everyone else goes "oink oink" to show how greedy you were). The player then has to ante another chip into the pot.

Whoever gets to 100 points gets all the chips in the pot and is the winner for that round.

(Note that despite the involvement of Peter Marshall and the use of "Celebrity" in the title, Celebrity Piggy was never actually a game show.)
publishers: E. S. Lowe Company Inc., Milton Bradley

name: Farscape The Card Game
description:
Card game based on the popular SCI-FI show Farscape. The object of the game is to have the highest score by the time the series (game) ends. There are Character cards, event cards, character exit cards and play change cards.
CHARACTERS in the game:
Pa'u Zotoh Zhaan - DelvianPriest
Aeryn Sun - Ex-PeaceKeeperCommando
Ka D'Argo - Luxan Warrior
Chiana - NebariThief
Dominar Rygel XVI - Hynerian Royalty
Commander John Crichton - HumanScientist
Captain Bilar Crais - PeaceKeeper Captain
Scorpius - PeaceKeeper Special Ops
SikozuSvalaSugaysiShanu - Kalish Biloid
Pilot - Pilot
Joolushko Tunay Hovalis - Interion Student
Utu-Noranti Pralatong - TraskanHerbologist
Stark - Banik Strykera
Jothee - Luxan Hybrid
Moya - Leviathan
Talyn - Leviathan Hybrid
Lieutenant Braca - PeaceKeeper Officer
Commandant Mele-On Grayza - PeaceKeeper Officer

Events are drawn from the event deck and have differing effects. When a characters Physical Health or Mental Health has been reduced to zero that character is out of the game. Their are also events that change rules of the game. (reverse direction, reduce hand size, play all cards on a turn not just one, hand size is increased from 5 to 7 and eventually the end of season card which ends the game.)
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Doomsday America
description: Doomsday America is a lighthearted apocalypse themed board and card game. The USA is divided up into 9 zones. Players have population counters in these zones. Players use disaster cards to eliminate their opponents' counters. Plagues, Pestilence, Locusts, Comets, Invasions, Zombies, it's all there. Score Victory points each turn for the zones you control. Depopulate 2 Zones to end the game. Free rule set available at: http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/DDA.html
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Science Fiction
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Bluff Mania
description:
Players take turns to pick a card, and play continues clockwise. One of the three words is chosen by the active player who reads it out. All write down an ingenious, unlikely or just plain silly definition.

The active player reads out all the definitions including the correct one. All other players decide what they think is the correct definition. Each player who chooses the correct definition scores a point. Authors of fictional definitions that are chosen also receive a point for each player who chose it.

The winner is the player with the most points after twenty rounds.

name: Megamaniology
description:
From the box:

"Ever wanted to be an evil genius, but lacked that degree in nuclear warping from a shady South American university? Now is your chance! Gather your body parts, chemicals and duct tape, stick your brain in a jar, and get to work with your deformed helper on that mind control beam you've wanted since high school gym class!"

Megamaniology is a simple card game about collecting ingredients to make the best experiment ever! First player to 23 points wins the game.

name: Big Brother Truth or Dare
description:
Big Brother Truth or Dare is an adult boardgame where players take turns answering opponents truth or dare cards.

The Truth or Dare cards contain more than 1,500 questions and each question has a corresponding level of naughtiness of either Prude, Rude or Lewd. Players progress around the board by moving the number of spaces indicated on each card - 1 for Prude, 2 for Rude and 3 for Lewd.

The winner is the first person to cross the finish line.

Dares range from "Play air guitar" through to "Snog another player", whilst questions include "When was the last time you were blindfolded?" and "Describe a love triangle you’ve been involved in."

name: Across the Dniepr: Kiev-Zhitomir '43
description:
This small game deals with the Soviet attack to liberate Kiev, Ukraine in November-December 1943 and the subsequent counterattack by Balck's 48th Panzerkorps (1st, 7th, 19th, 25th, 1st SS Leibstandarte, 2nd SS Das Reich panzerdivisions and the 68th infantry division) against the 3rd Guard Tank army of Rybalko, the 38th and 60th armies, on Zhitomir, Korosten and the Malin pocket. After a quick Soviet initial advance overwhelmed the German defenders and liberated Kiev, the German counterattack with fresh reinforcements coming from other theaters of operations, destroyed several Soviet units, but could not regain much of the lost territory and was too weak to reach Kiev.

11 X 17 inches map, 64 counters, divisional level for the Germans plus the 506th Tiger battalion and corps level for the Russians.

name: Triple Cross: Modern Chess
description:
Three player chess on a hexagonal board with three colors for spaces.

Also three Bishops (one per color of space for each player) and Knights that start the game in a third rank behind the main setup.

name: Hustle
description: Dexterity game in which players take turns trying to capture small balls under a cup, each ball has a string attached to it, given the other players a chance to yank each ball clear before it's captured.

name: Kletterbaum
description:
A dice rolling game of isolation.

On the large, 10 x 6 squares measuring playing surface, 60 colour coded cards are spread out, showing the backside with 6 different coloured circles.

Players beging to move their pawns from the bottom of the board, digging their way into the cards.
If the colour on the die is the same as on an adjacent card, you can take the card and move on as long as you can pick up a card.
If you succeed to isolate a certain number of cards against the borders of the board, you can take them all.

On the front of the cards several 2-part pictures are depicted, winner is the player who is able to fix together the most complete pictures.

name: Lee at Gettysburg: The Battle for Cemetery Ridge (Gold Edition)
description:
Lee at Gettysburg: The Battle for Cemetery Ridge - Gold Edition is a substantial reworking of the game that originally appeared in the Armchair General. Counters represent the brigades, leaders, and batteries that Lee at Gettysburg... Lock n Load Publishing fought on the first day of the Gettysburg. Leaders are critical not only rallying their troops but enhancing their attacks as well.

New in the Gold Edition are facing rules, enhanced leader capabilities retreats that can route an entire line of troops, and a completely new layout of the rules, charts, and scenarios. And speaking of scenarios, Gold Edition revises one of the original scenarios and adds two more, bringing the Gold Edition scenario total to four.

UPDATE:

This game has been redeveloped by the new LnLP staff improving the counters, maps, rules, and scenarios in the game. You can find the new edition at

https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/229356/lee-gettysburg-ju...

or

https://store.lnlpublishing.com/category/battles-on-demand/l...

If you have purchased Omaha: The Battle for the Beach at the current LnLP Store, we will provide you a FREE Print and Play edition that you can be download from your order history from the LnLP Store.

Print On Demand Edition: The Print On Demand Edition includes full color printed, manual, player aid cards, larger maps, and counters printed on Sticker sheets and chit board to mount them on. Once you received your game you will be all ready to play. The Print and Play edition is included for free with our Print On Demand Edition.

Print and Play Edition: The Print and Play Edition is available as a downloadable Print and Play files that can be printed in both US Letter and A4 paper sizes. Our Print and Play Edition includes individual files for the manual, player aid cards, counters and smaller multi-part maps for home printers and larger map files that can be printed at a local print shop. You may select to purchase only Print and Play Edition and reduce the price of the game under the Available Options on the product page.

Re-implements:

Lee at Gettysburg: The Battle for Cemetery Ridge
categories: American Civil War, Print & Play, Wargame

name: The Crazy Gift Game
description:
From the designers homepage:

The Crazy Gift Game, a true party game! Have all your guests bring one or more small, big, funny, strange and crazy gifts and play The Crazy Gift Game to see who ends up with the most gifts in the end!

Let the cards send the gifts to one and then another person! See the Lucky Lot go and disappear - and maybe grow again! A whole new kind of party game!

The Crazy Gift Game can be used at parties of up to 15 participants. For more participants: simply add a set of Crazy Gift Game cards. 1 set extra for up to 30 and two sets for up to 50 participants!

name: Spinjas
description: Spinjas is a ratcheted spinning top game created by Parker Brothers in the late 1980s. The game set was sold as a Battle Stadium plastic arena with two Power Winder launchers and two Spinja characters enclosed within the clam-shell designed arena. More characters, launchers, and an oversized playing arena were also made available separately. The objective of the game is to load your chosen character into the ratcheting launcher and each player would launch their top into the arena at the same time. The tops would ricochet off of each other until only one remained spinning or within the arena and that player was declared the winner.The tops are not customizable and are not associated with any other licensed properties.

name: Spicheren
description:
Game appeared in the magazine Casus Belli (Issue 15 - Jun 1983).
Map of 41x 30 cm with 99 counters. It reproduces the battle of the french-prussian war of Spicheren of the 6 of August of 1870.

name: ¡Europa!
description: Players compete to fullfil an itinerary around Europe answering questions about the Old Continent and its institutions.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move
publishers: Oficina en España del Parlamento Europeo

name: Scrimmage
description:
Scrimmage was invented by Chuck Eskridge, and David Williams. It is a football game in which one side controls the offense and the other controls the defense. Movement is accomplished by dice rolls, with slower players have lower maximum movement capability. Each side has pieces (players) of varying strength and speed. Any player can tackle any other player, but only players of equal or greater strength can block opposing players. The offense sets up, and then the defense, with a twist: the defense does not know whether the offense is running a passing play or a running play. (The choice is disclosed after the play starts.) If it is a passing play, the pass can be thrown to a designated grid but only after the play has had time to develop. If a play breaks down, the offensive player draws a card to determine whether he can recover.

The passing mechanism works wonderfully: the offense places two men downfield in one of several grids, and secretly chooses a card identifying the grid to which the pass will be made. Each team then moves players (including the potential receivers) with the roll of the dice. When the pass is made, the offense chooses which square in the grid the pass will go to. The choice of squares determines how easy it is for the receiver and the defensive back(s) to get to the square to which the pass is made: if the receiver gets to the square and the back does not, the pass is complete. If the back gets to the square and the receiver does not, the pass is intercepted. If both get to the square, the pass is incomplete.

The running game and the pass rush depend on the the success of the blockers and the defensive line. There is luck in the dice rolls, of course, but the luck evens out over the course of the game and a good play can survive a little bad luck. Card drawing can also be important. Sometimes tacklers reach the ball carrier but fail to make the tackle, or make the tackle and force a fumble, which can be recovered by either the offense of defense.

This is one of the few games non-simulation football games (i.e., not strat-o-matic football or its cousins) that really feels like you are playing football. You choose your play in advance, and, like real football, sometimes it works as planned, sometimes it fails, and sometimes you have to improvise during the course of the play.

Only about 800 copies of the game were sold, primarily in game stores in the South. Two versions were created, the original version and a second version that included an optional "monster man" with good speed and power.

This game is not to be confused with the SPI game of the same name-- and almost the same year.
mechanics: Hand Management, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Kriegspiel Junior
description:
The gameboard shows a battlefield containing Berlin and Vienna at one end and Paris and Brussels at the other (which appear to be represented by 3 gold circles). Additional the map has fortresses (gold point walled in) and is dominated by a river running down the middle.

The game mechanics are an unknown at this point but its a point to point movement system.
categories: Children's Game, Wargame, World War I
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Klutz Book of Card Games: for Sharks and Others
description: The Klutz Book of Card Games for Sharks & Others is the complete Klutz-proof instructions (including diagrams, photos, cartoons, blueprints, strategy, etc.) for the best 20 card games in the galaxy! From Old Maid to Gin Rummy.

name: Bolsão de Craques
description: In this game, the players are acting as soccer managers, trying to complete your team in the best way, and also trying not lose points because another soccer team's actions.

name: Campanha Da França 1940
description:
França: 1940 was the second game in the JOG series of wargames, published in Brazil on a subscription-only basis. It covers the German invasion of France and the Low Countries in 1940.

The game includes a "what-if" scenario where the French did not build the Maginot line, but instead used the funds to modernize their army.

name: BSO FOOTBALL
description:
BSO FOOTBALL
THE HISTORY OF PRO FOOTBALL

For fans of Tabletop Sports games, and Football, here is one of, if not THE, best solitaire play football card/board game ever. BSO FOOTBALL provides its players with remarkable statistical accuracy in almost every category, in the most accessible, playable form in the game industry. There’s no trying to outguess yourself on offense or defense. You just call the play and roll the dice (which you provide). Player Cards, one for every offensive player on the team, the Defensive Ratings on the Team Charts, and the Results Tables do the rest.

Check the sample Player Cards, above, to see how players are rated.

The Team Charts provide the ratings/information for Defense, Interceptions, Clutch Play, Fumbles, Penalties, and the full range of Returns and Kicking details. They also have Extra Information on Special and Unusual plays that team used. The Charts include Rushing, Pass Completion, Pass Gain and Return, Out-of-Bounds, Medium and Long Gains, Kickoff (including Onside Kicks), Punting (including Blocked Kicks), and a full range of Penalties.

The Game Clock is also extremely accurate, with each quarter using 180 “points”, each point equal to 5 seconds. A normal play would use 8 points, but an incomplete pass or Time Out only 1.

The first edition of BSO FOOTBALL brings you one of the greatest seasons in the History of Football, 1958, with the famous overtime Championship game between the Colts and the Giants. In the East the Giants and the Cleveland Browns, led by the great Jim Brown, had to use a playoff game to determine the winner, and the Steelers, led by the veteran Bobby Layne, were not that far behind. In the West, the Colts beat out both the Bears and Rams by one game.

Some of Pro Football’s greats are present: Ollie Matson, Norm Van Brocklin, Johnny Unitas, Jon Arnett, Y. A. Tittle, and the first glimpses of Bart Starr, Jim Taylor, and Paul Hornung, all playing for one of the worst Green Bay teams ever (1-10-1)! And wait’ll you see the average yards per pass catch! Steeler rookie, Jimmy Orr, led the league with 27.6, with many others not far behind.

For gamers who like to play entire seasons and revel in great statistical accuracy, BSO FOOTBALL is unbeatable. And, if you wish, there are special rules for face-to-face play, which use extended play calling (although, to be up front, that is not the game’s strong point).

player cards: 150
team cards” 12
others: Charts, Schedules, Rules
cost: $14 US; $15 Canada; $17 Pacific

name: Rommel: The Campaign for North Africa
description:
Rommel: The Campaign for North Africa by Loren F. Sperry, self published.

1 22" x 34" map of the campaign area from El Agheila to just east of El Alamein. Turn scale is 3 turns to the month from Sept 1940 to Dec 1942. 252 1/2 counters (very thin perforated cardboard) represent the divisions, regiments, brigades and strength breakdown counters.

Game play is a simple move then fight. Supply is a bit tougher in that all units must be with 5 hexes of a supply unit, which are expended for combat.

There are some chrome rules, minefields, fortifications, recon units.

name: Martian Life
description:
An Icehouse game based on Conway's Game of Life. It requires one stash of pyramids per player and one chess-board. Each turn, a player places a small onto an empty space, or grows one of their existing pieces (small to medium, or medium to large). Then dead pieces are removed simultaneously from the entire board. As in Conway's Game of Life, a piece's survival depends on the number of adjacent neighbors: smalls need 1-3 neighbors, mediums need 3-5 neighbors, and larges need 5-7 neighbors to survive.

Rules Link
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Pattern Building, Simulation

name: Martian Frisby
description:
Martian Frisby is an Icehouse game. It is played using nestable Icehouse game pieces, a chessboard, and dice.

Like Mrs. Frisby, you must move your nest to safety. And like a Martian, you must obey the Laws of the Pyramids.

You start with six pieces nested at one end of a chessboard. Roll the dice, and try to move all your pieces to the other end of the board. Along the way, you may nest pieces, but you may never stack them.

Rules Link
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Calgary On Board
description: Calgary On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in the province of Alberta, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Theatre Calgary and the Calgary Stampede Foundation.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Billings On Board
description: Billings On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Montana City. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Ronald McDonald House of Billings.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Pacific Salvo!
description: Pacific Salvo! is a stand-alone game module that may be used on its own, or in conjunction with any previously published modules of the system. Pacific Salvo! contains the basic Salvo! game rules (in the form of the postcard game which includes ten ships, a sheet for 48 ships from World War II Pacific fleets, and a rules folder containing optional rules, scenarios, and Ship Roster. (From the intro to the game.)
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame, World War II

name: Spanish Fury, Siege!
description:
This gamette (actually a full game on it's own) will allow you to play out a siege of a Sixteenth century Town or Fortress from the pounding of the first spade into the earth to the capture of the town square!
Included are two maps, one of a town on a river and one of a coastal port, counters for companies of Foot, Horse, Pioneers and Cannon, and a complete generation system for creating your own scenarios quickly and easily.
categories: Pike and Shot, Print & Play, Renaissance, Wargame

name: Subbuteo Hockey
description: Subbuteo Hockey is a reworking of the popular finger-flicking soccer-simulation game. This game was designed to appeal to girls as the 1981 Subbuteo cataloge states "The first Subbuteo game produced for girls, this is the table-top replica of one of the World's fastest growing female sports."

name: Abracadabra
description:
Children's game consisting of a central game board with 9 different illustrations, and 36 tiles that each have one of those illustrations on them. The players take turns picking a tile and placing it in front of them, where it has to touch a previous tile horizontally or vertically, as shown on the central board. The first to get all 9 wins.

A variant has the players place the tiles directly on the central game board and try to form three-in-a-row.

name: Master Europa 103: Western Front – Blitzkrieg
description: Master Europa is a complete set of rules and charts replacing those in the games of the Europa series. This module covers the games "Fall of France" & "Their Finest Hour". It contains 19 new counters for use with the logistics system, 3 for the German OOB, and 49 for use with the naval system . It also includes Orders Of Battle (OOB) that allow a scenario showing the Western Front from Sept. 1939 on to be explored.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Dan Russell's Hockey Trivia
description: Compete against your friends answering the personal favorite hockey trivia questions of long time Vancouver sports radio talk show host Dan Russell. The game focusses on questions about the Vancouver Canucks.

name: Black-Out!
description:
The game consists of a deck of cards supplied with a box and rules card. It is described as a 'Topical Card game' by the publishers. The subject matter abstractly & comically (for 1939, that is!) portrays the blackout period in England during the German bombing raids of early World War two.
The pack of cards consist of five suits (Silhouettes, Fashions, Search-Lights, Views, & Lights)and are numbered from two to twelve (minus the numbers six and nine)for the purpose of scoring. Additionally there five Black Out cards that provide the blocking element of the game and are valued at one point.
Play consists of each player in turn playing a card from hand to table, face up, from the hand dealt (six cards for up to three players and five cards for four or five players). Each player builds a personal collection by adding either an identical number or suit to the card previously played. If a player is unable to do so, a card must be taken into the hand from the stock of cards not dealt. There is a blocking element of play by the use of Black Out cards which may be placed on an opponents pile in order to stop cards from being played on that pile and forces the player to play cards on other players piles.
The first player to play all cards ends the round and each players played cards are scored. The game is played up to 200 points.

name: Der Boss
description: Players travel on a game board allowing them to draft cards, which are used to place men in cities on five continents, where they can build business networks and monopolies. When two players vie for the same area, a dice battle resolves the conflict. Special actions allow players extra placements, card draws, or other bonuses.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Worker Placement

name: Puigcardener
description:
Puigcardener is a game by Oriol Comas for the exhibition Cinc mil anys jugant ("Five thousand years playing games") organized by Caixa Manresa and the Toy Museum of Catalonia in Figueres. It is an abstract game freely based on the first populations established around the hill that nowadays is the city of Manresa, about 2,500 years ago.

The five counters of each of the four colors are placed initially along the four sides of the board. In a 4-player game each player controls a color; in a 2-player game each player controls two colors. The objective is to lead all the counters of your color to the opposite side of the board. By turn each player moves one of his counter one space ahead or captures an enemy counter diagonally.

name: Moka
description:
Explained in Gladstone's Games to Go, Moka is an abstract strategy game played on a 6x6 board, where the players vie to create a horizontal, vertical, or diagonal line of three of their playing pieces, all with the same side up.

From Gladstone’s Games to Go:

Moka was invented by Jay Laird and Mark Rosenstein in a series of brainstorming sessions during the late 1990s. The two would play at their favorite Boston and Cambridge cafes, including the late, lamented beanery that lent the game its name. Though Moka can be played anywhere with coins or pen and paper, there’s a certain charming resourcefulness to using sugar packets for markers if you happen to be playing in your favorite coffee shop.

name: Raketny Kreyser
description:
Raketny Kreyser: Tactical Naval Combat, 1975-1999, is a game simulation of tactical naval warfare as it might occur in the late 1970's thru the 1990's.

The naval and/or naval air forces of the U.S., the U.S.S.R., the U.K., the P.R.C., Canada, Turkey, Greece, Norway, Denmark, Sweden, W.Germany, E.Germany, Poland, Finland, Iraq, Iran, N.Korea, S.Korea, Japan, Taiwan, Italy, India, and France are represented by their major combatants and aircraft.

The publisher referred to this as “A broad spectrum survey of the naval and naval air units that would be engaged in any major world conflict from now until the turn of the century. Three groups of scenarios (Gulfs and Straits, Coastal Seas, Open Ocean) depict likely places of conflict and participants. Silhouette type counters cover the major combatants of over a dozen nations. Back printing has been used to conceal a unit’s identity and attack values. Surface effect ships and semi-submerged platforms depict future naval trends. Ranged attacks, air detection zones, NTDS, and
optional rules covering weather in all the world’s oceans and systems reliability allow players to realistically simulate modern naval combat.”

The designer noted: "This one was supposed to be the simple game of the three for that year. It was, and was perhaps too simple. With only air and surface elements represented, it was a clean and fast game of modern naval combat, but not the full story. It was fast and violent though, and sold out quickly. We redid the concept (much more to my satisfaction) some years later with Battle Stations."

Raketny Kreyser is the rarest of the Simulation Canada board games; only 550 were printed.

Game Scale:
Turn: 12 minutes
Hex: 1 nautical mile / 1.8 kilometers
Units: Individual ships or three aircraft

Game Inventory:
One 22 x 18" featureless blue mapsheet
One dual-side printed countersheet (255 1/2" counters)
One 12-page Raketny Kreyser rules booklet (5.5"x8.5")

name: Explore!
description:
Explore! The African Adventure Game!

Synopsis from the rule sheet:

"Welcome to EXPLORE! - the gripping game which takes you to the fascinating continent of Africa.

You are the explorer, searching for the aerie of the mysterious Black Eagle, high on the peaks of the extinct volcano.

Race through tropical forests, over the mountain, deep into darkest caves, or under the veil of the glittering waterfall. You will trek across the desert, wade through swamp and crocodile-infested rivers and struggle to find a way through thorny scrub. You will find out about the wealth of animals that live in these different habitats."
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Giebo Giedze
description: Giebo Giedze is a traditional Tibetan board game for two players. One player has two kings and the other one 24 Queens. The aim of the player with the kings is to jump over the Queens to kill them all, and the aim of the player with the Queens is to block the kings' movement, like in the Nepal board game Bagh Chal.

name: Teploie
description:
Teploie, "Las colinas de hierro" ("The iron heights") is a wargame included in Alea Magazine number 7 (March-April 1990).

The game portrays the battle for the Teploie village and heights during the July 1943 Kursk offensive. The German units are part of Army Group Center. One hex represents 1 km.
Game includes a small map (42x29 cm), one countersheet with 160 counters, and eight pages of rules. The CRT and Terrain Effects Chart are printed on the back of the map, so they should be photocopied. Next Alea (number 8, May-June 1990) includes errata, additions and clarifications for the game.

name: Black Fire
description:
This expansion adds magic-user characters, and allows games with up to 10 players.

Expands:

Blood Master.

name: España en llamas
description:
"España en llamas" is a special issue of Spanish magazine "Wargames, soldados y estrategia", which also has an English language version called, of course, "Wargames, Soldiers and Strategy".
The magazine has 138 pages and it adapts the Spanish Civil War to the "Flames of War" miniatures rules system.
The first pages are a historical introduction to the conflict,while the rest has several army lists, scenarios and missions for the game.
The magazine also includes an extra boardgame about the Spanish Civil War too, "El eco de los pasos" (see entry).

name: The Great Word Race
description:
Publishers description:

"Children of all ages will have fun challenging their spelling skills while playing The Great Word Race! You'll never believe spelling can be such a blast. Race your pawn from start to finish by moving it the number of letters in the word you build. Throw six dice with the letters of the alphabet. Add any Letter for Life cards you have collected. If you land on a Pick A Card square, use it! Should you collect Letter for Life cards, double your spaces, or Pick a Card and follow its instructions. Choose your strategy and race for the finish!"

For 2 to 4 players. Ages 6 and up.

name: Salvanèl: flight from the enchanted wood
description:
Who is the Salvanèl?
The Salvanèl is a goblin that frequently appears in the legends of Trentino, in northern Italy. Until not many decades ago, in every valley you could find someone who said they had seen the Salvanèl, even though actually encountering him was extremely unlikely.
They described him as a small man, boyish-looking, and always with some red feature on him: a hat, clothes or hair.

This time the Salvanèl, running to and fro, has left his magical tracks everywhere. Anyone who treads on them by mistake is bound to get lost - and after much wandering, finds himself back where he started. Now you are lost in the wood too!
To get back home you must make three good moves to reconstruct a path that will take you out of the wood. But the goblin will also help you, if you meet him!

At the beginning of every turn, the guide picks a colored card. This card has two effects:
1-The Salvanèl immediately moves toward the border indicated by the card, and if he meets a player... He immediately gains an extra turn!
2-The player indicated by the card plays his turn... And if he meets the Salvanèl... He plays again!

In every turn, players can use one of these moves:
1-Spin:choose a tile and rotate it in any direction you like
2-Puff of Wind: move one or more tiles of a horizontal or vertical line
3-Jump: move your token from the tile where it is to another one next to it.

The first player who jumps out of any tile on the side of his colour wins!

name: ab, durch die mitte!
description: Ab, durch die Mitte is an easily understandable tactics game for 2 or 4 people, where the point is, to be the first to have their pawns disappear through the hole in the center of the game box.

name: The Recess Dungeon Game
description:
The Recess Dungeon Game is a competitive dungeon crawl where players run Heroes through a dark maze looking for the Dragon and the Dragon's Treasure. The first Player to exit his or her Hero from the Dungeon with the Dragon's Treasure is the winner.

Features rules for doors, traps, magic treasure, monsters, Hero to Hero combat, and more.

Game requires one player to take on the role of the Referee. Simple game with high replayability. Adaptable to any setting fictional or other. Games are short and brutal with high Hero mortality.
Referee may participate in game by running a special Hero called the Villain.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Hydropolis
description:
Hydropolis is an abstract city-building game using the components of the game Waterworks. The "city" starts with one card in the center of the table. Each turn, you play a card from your hand, score points based on its location relative to other cards, add that play's score to your cumulative score, and then draw a card. One by one, the table is filled with a contorted maze of pipes. The game ends when all players pass or when somebody reaches a set amount of points. and the player with the highest running score wins. But if you earn three Golden Wrenches first, you win automatically!

Complete rules and revision history is available at:
http://ceruleansgames.tripod.com/hydropolis.htm
mechanics: Modular Board, Network and Route Building, Pattern Building, Tile Placement

name: Goofball Rally
description:
Publishers Description:

"It’s time for Goofball Rally, the fast-paced, color-matching marble race! Place your goofballs on the starting line and get ready to go. On your mark, get set…roll! Launch your goofballs one by one down the winding race tracks. When all of your goofballs have crossed the finish line, hit the red button. The first player to score 20 points is the Goofball Rally Champ! Includes goofball stadium game board, 10 race cards, and 20 goofball racers (in 10 bright colors). For 2 players."

name: Victory
description:
This is a clever game of setting up collections.

Regarding the time it was published, the theme of the game and last but not least the comic strip caricatures of Churchill, Hitler and some other populars of the time this is one of the rarest and for the collector most expensive game from the Pepys company.

Object of the game is to secure points for merit. This is done by rising in the services (Army, Navy, Air Force and Home Services) in proper sequences, avoiding to include one of the penalty villains of Hitler-ruled Germany.

Clever card drafting and discarding rules coupled with nail-biting decision when to end a round (enhance your set or take the risk to draw a penalty) is even by modern standards a good game.

By the time this game was published the card quality was very high: thick cardboard with linen finish and brightly coloured printing add to the flair of the game.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, World War II

name: Martian Shogi
description:
Players sit at opposite sides of the board. The pieces are oriented to point away from a player to show that that player controls them. The remaining pyramids are placed in a common area off the board that is available to both players. To show that neither player owns any of these pyramids initially, they should be in this "global stash" standing upright. There are also two initially empty off-board "prisoner areas", one near each player, to hold the pieces captured by that player. The object of the game is to capture all of an opponent's Monarchs (large blue pieces). There are twelve different pieces in the game, each with a unique movement.

Design Competitions

Ice Game Design Competition - Entry in 1st Competition

name: Missile Command
description:
Each player secretly chooses 24 “Missiles” (pyramids), eight of each size, and combines them into a Battery of eight “Missile Silos” (stacks of pyramids).

Each player also secretly conceals their President and Vice President tokens under one or two of the Missile Silos.

Players take turns launching one Missile (removing one pyramid from one stack) at one specific exposed Missile in an enemy Battery. Both pyramids are discarded exposing whatever is underneath.

Eventually, the Silo protecting the President is exhausted and the President herself is exposed. Once exposed, the President can be struck by an enemy Missile, eliminating the owning player.

Play continues until only one President remains (one player winner) – OR – all remaining Presidents are exposed at the same time (a draw).

Game System

Icehouse Pieces


Design Competitions

Ice Game Design Competition - Entry in 1st Competition

name: Tank Extravaganza
description:
Players are famous tank manufacturers of World War II, such as Krupp and Vickers, aiming to build the best tank of WWII.

Game comes with 108 "Magic: The Gathering"-sized cards.

This game is the third in the series from the same game designer, after Naval Competition and Prototype Competition.
categories: Card Game, Wargame, World War II

name: Maus pass auf!
description:
From back of box

Sniff, sniff ... it smells like cheese!
Oskar, the cheeky mouse creeps closer to outwit the cheese.
but alas, the mousecatcher lies in wait!
He tries to catch the mouse before he reaches his goal.
Who wins - mouse or mousecatcher?

The purpose of the game is to prevent the other player from reaching the mouse hole. This can be done Oscar the "sneaky" little mouse, and his sister, Lilly, sit in their mouse apartment drinking tea. "Sniff, sniff...," something smells like cheese! From the church kitchen over the stairs, the smell of cheese fill the whole apartment. Will they try to "sneak" a piece of cheese? Will they be caught by the mouse catcher?"

One player plays the mouse who is trying to get to a square with the cheese without getting caught. The mouse moves by rolling a custom die that has a one, two, three and a X on it. Once the player has moved, the mouse catcher rolls the die and places that many red gates around the mouse trying to trap it. The game ends when either the mouse has gotten to the cheese or the mouse catcher has trapped the mouse.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Enclosure, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Leaning Towers
description:
Players stack pyramids, not allowing them to touch more pieces than the number of pips on the piece.

* Each player must place a piece of a different size than the previous placement. (The first piece placed on the Foundation is not affected by this rule.)
* The point of one piece cannot touch the inside point of another piece
* A piece can be placed on top of another piece as long as it does not violate these rules
* Pieces must be placed with one hand
* A player cannot touch any pieces other than one the being placed (unless reassembling after a break)

More information can be found on the Icehouse Wiki or on the designer's site.

Game System

Icehouse Pieces

name: That's Truckin'
description:
Players get paid for delivering freight. The object of the game is to be the first player to pay for his or her truck, that is, to reach $40,000.00.

Players select from a hand of load sheets, which indicate i) where a player picks up a load, ii) where that load is to be delivered, iii) the fee for delivering the load, and iv) the bonus fee if the load is delivered within a certain number of days. A day is a player's turn. The roll of a die determines how far a player may travel on his turn. A player's truck may carry up to two loads at one time.

The key to the game is in the efficient use of the load sheets. For example, do you take just one load across country and go for that big bonus, or do you double up on the loads, which will slow you down and probably cost you a bonus, but will give you an extra payday? You also try to minimize the travel time in which the truck is empty by arranging for the next pick up to be near the just-reached destination.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Arena
description: Arena, Mini-Game #23 by Bad Baby Productions, is a download, print and play PDF boardgame. Create a gladiator, train him or her in the skills of killing and then equip them with the weapons and armor of your choice. Send them into the arena to battle other warriors to see who is the best, the toughest, the bravest warrior in the lands. System is expandable, with some expansions available to the system, including a detailed magic system.

name: Ambush
description:
Ambush is an abstract strategy game for 2 players. Two Icehouse stashes and 4 Martian Coasters are needed, one per player. Players will either play one of their 15 pyramids on the board or set a pyramid aside to rotate a coaster. Either action may allow them to capture a pyramid belonging to their opponent.

Game System

Icehouse Pieces

name: Gruftmeister Adventure
description:
From the publisher's web site:
"The new dimension in dungeon-games

Gruftmeister Adventure says goodbye to dice and chance-oriented fighting-systems. Here you fight the undead with your skill.

Up to four players explore the crypt of count Gramwuml in search for treasure. Behind every door there's fear: Go to the arena and fight. Playing a cryptrunner, thief, fighter or magician, you try to beat the other players. But even when there's no other player, Gruftmeister Adventure can be played as a solo-adventure.

Players start at the skeleton of count Gramwuml. From there they explore the crypt room by room, adding new floor tiles. Use actions to explore the crypt, open doors, fight undead or cast spells. Once you encounter a closed door or a coffin, you go to the arena and fight with your skills. A real challenge for both younger and older players. Finally no more orgies of throwing dice.

Gruftmeister Adventure is a totally new game, you don't need an older version of Gruftmeister. Everything needed for the adventure is included: 18 floor-tiles for all-new adventures every time, 140 cards for monsters, treasures, doors, spells, more than 100 wooden pieces, the fighting arena with all the parts for thrilling duels."

Re-implements:

Gruftmeister

name: Tank Battles in Miniature 4: A wargamers' guide to the Mediterranean Campaigns 1943-1945
description:
From the dust jacket:
"This, the fourth title in the Tank Battles in Miniature series, deals with Allied and German armoured operations in Tunisia, Sicily, Italy and southern France. It explains tank usage and tactics, includes valuable data on the weapons and vehicles employed, and contains numerous wargame playing suggestions."
Fourth book in the series, a valuable reference for gamers and game designers.
publishers: Patrick Stephens Limited, The History of Wargaming Project

name: Lightning
description:
Connection game in which players draw random tiles and place them to complete a line across the long length of their board. Each player has a board, but on their play may play on either their board or their opponent's.

Instead of placing the tile on the board, it may be placed in a face-up draw pool to be optionally accessed in later turns by both players.

There are 150 tiles: 30 each of 5 different types.

Placements must connect to your previous "lightning bolt". Should it become blocked, you must spur from the closest valid spot.

Patented in 1892, it is believed to be the first connection game.

name: Máš na to!
description:
This is a quiz game for two players or teams, where players try to name as many items as they can in particular categories. The game is played with 15 cards that list various categories, and a nice wooden teetotum with six sides that affects scoring. The sides of the teetotum show: +1, -1, 1X, 1X, 2X and a joker.
The game is bilingual, having rules and text in both Czech and Slovak.

At the Dino website, the game is listed in English as 'Quicky', although no English version is available.

The game designer and year of manufacture is not stated. The illustrations are credited to Jiří Pros.

name: Straits
description:
Straits is a Chess-like game for two, played on a 9 x 11 hourglass-shaped grid of checkered squares. Each player has nineteen pieces of his own color: one Flag-ship, 7 Turret-ships, 8 Torpedo boats, and 3 Gun-boats. Their rules of movement are as follows:

)Flag-ship - it moves and captures like a Queen in Chess, but it cannot be captured and must not move into check or remain in check.
)Turret-ship - it moves and captures like a Rook in Chess.
)Torpedo boat - it moves and captures like a Bishop in Chess, and is consequently bound to squares of the same color.
)Gun-boat - it moves one square in any direction, but can capture only diagonally.

The first player to move his Flag-ship to the board's central square or who checkmates the Flag-ship of his opponent wins the game.

name: Once Upon a Time in the Western Peninsula
description: Skirmish wargame rules for the Napoleonic period. Despite the name the game is not merely focused on the Peninsular war. Three scenarios are included.

name: Open Season
description: This is a hunting game that consists of driving out to the hunting lodge, spending 5 days (laps around the lodge area) hunting, then driving back home. Aside from rolling dice to determine how far to move the game is played primarily with a big composite spinner, which determines the outcome of things like shooting game, luck at the horse track, and playing poker. Everyone starts with $300 and 5 credentials. Driving is mostly uneventful except for small financial transactions. Luck "in the field" is determined by flipping over situation cards when you land on situation space. Some cards have animals you can try to shoot at, others have bad luck type situations you need to over come by moving or playing a credential card. Each time a player circumnavigates the lodge (spends one day hunting) they receive a credential and have an opportunity to answer a hunting or safety related question for a cash bonus.

name: Advanced Culture & Conquest
description: A card game based on the rise of ancient civilizations. The cards represent Advancements, Cities, Leaders, Wonders, and Events. The players build Cities and Wonders, establish trade (to gain Advancements held by opponents), and start wars. The possibility of catastrophic events always looms in the background. The object of the game is to have the most Victory Points after the deck has been gone through twice.

name: Conan
description:
“Create your own tales of Conan the Barbarian and his adventures in Hyboria. All players share a single common deck. The deck contains six suits of cards: Conan cards, Locations, Events, Lesser Foes, Major Foes, & Specials. There are 30+ cards of each suit in the deck.”

The object of the game is to score the most victory points by playing melds from your six card hand. There are four types of melds that may be played: Three Pairs (two cards each from three suits), Two Three-of-a-Kinds (three cards each from two suits), Six-of-a-kind (six cards from one suit), or Flush (one card from each suit).

name: Classic Dungeon Crawl
description:
“This simple card and dice miniature game is based off of the very original Dungeons and Dragons, back in the days of Chainmail and the Classic Dungeons and Dragons boxed set. If the game rules seem a bit simple and occasionally clumsy, they are supposed to be. That was the charm of the ‘Proto-D&D’ fantasy miniature wargaming.”

“This game can be played with 1 to 3 players. For solo play, this is a simple solitaire adventure system for ‘proto-D&D’ fantasy miniature battles. For two to three players, it becomes a competition to survive (be warned that multiplayer games can get very lengthy; it’s best to take this game in sessions like you would a modern D&D adventure, breaking between dungeon levels.)”

Each dungeon level uses a different deck of cards composed of the types of monsters found on that level of the dungeon. On each turn the player draws the top card from the deck for the dungeon level his character is on and fights the monster. If the player’s character is killed, the player is out of the game. If the monster is defeated, the player receives gold and experience points. A certain number of experience points is required to advance to the lower dungeon levels.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Variable Player Powers

name: Celtic Skirmish
description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. Minor Battle between two Celtic War Bands. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single man (unit). Victory: You win if you kill the opposing Chieftain.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the men, which come in three types: Chieftans, Champions, and Warriors. A custom deck of cards plays a central role in the game. The players draw a hand of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

name: East Front West Front
description: “Card game for 2 players simulating the conflict in Europe in the Second World War. One player is the Germans, the other is the Allies. Each player has his own unique deck. Fronts: There are three fronts: The East Front, the West Front, the Mediterranean Front. Each front is represented by 4 Tokens. (There are 4 East, 4 West, & 4 Med. Tokens) Victory: If the Allied player controls all 4 tokens in any one front he wins. To win, the German player must control all 4 tokens in both the East and West Fronts. If the Germans do not win by the end of 1945, they automatically lose.”

name: Age of Enlightenment
description:
"Card game for 2-4+ players. Theme: Age of Reason 18th Century. Players try to claim the most/best people and ideas from The Age of Enlightenment."

The game is played with two custom decks, the Personage Deck and the Discovery Deck. Only Personage Cards are held in a player's hand. The Discovery Cards are drawn and distributed for scoring purposes.

"The game ends when both decks have been used up.
The player with the most Enlightenment points wins." Each Discovery Card has a specified point value. Points are also awarded for having the most cards in a category (such as scientists, philosophers, and musicians.)

name: Panzer
description:
Panzer is a free print & play, card driven, armor combat game on a tactical level set in World War II for 2 players.

The game is played on hex maps with a scale of 500 meters per hex. Statistics are given for German, British, French, American and Russian tanks, and two German anti-tank guns. Each unit is rated for speed, armor, and penetration. Counters are used to represent the tanks, guns and various combat and terrain effects.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from a common deck affecting the way units move and attack. Intelligent and timely card play are paramount to achieving victory.

Panzer's design is clean and elegant with smooth mechanics and easy to learn, intuitive rules yet engrossing gameplay, perfectly suited for those new to board wargaming. Easy to set up, with sessions lasting about 45 minutes, Panzer has nearly unlimited replayability.
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Wargame, World War II

name: Fall of Manjukuo
description:
Fall of Manjukuo is a division-scale game based on the invasion of Manjukuo by Soviet forces during the closing days of World War II. One player takes the role of all of the commanders of the Soviet and Outer Mongolian Forces, while the other player takes the role of all commanders of the Axis (Manjukuo, Inner Mongolia and Japan) forces.

A complete copy of Fall of Manjukuo includes a 6-sheet maxi-contrast monochromatic map, a four-page rule book, two unique counter sheets (pink and blue), a terrain effects and time record chart, and two combat result tables. To play, you also need an icosahedral (0-9, twice) die, which is not supplied with the game."
(quoted from the rules)

This hand-drawn game was published in the Strategy Gaming Society's newsletter "Strategist".

name: Joust: The Card Game
description:
"Two player card game simulating a joust between two competing knights. Victory: Be the first player to win 3 passes."

"The Deck: Players share a common deck. The Cards: There are four suites: 1. Speed, 2. Aim, 3. Armor, 4. Courage. Each card belongs to one Suite and has a force value from 1 to 10."

Each hand the players receive four cards face up and eight cards face down. The players must discard four of their face down cards. All of the cards are revealed and the players total the value of their cards in each suit. The goal of each hand is to have the highest score in the most number of suits. The player who does so wins the pass.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Medieval, Print & Play, Sports

name: Dimension Defender
description:
This is a (relatively) straightforward card battle game that includes a pun (or two). The "fighter" cards that battle are futuristic spaceships called "Multi-dimension Attack Ships" (M*A*S), yeah, you can say "mass." There are cards that destroy an opponent's M*A*S. That card is called, of course, a "Weapon of M*A*S Destruction" (we warned you).

That is a very powerful card, so before you are allowed to play it, you must announce it. If opponent has a Search card, he gets to search some of your cards to try to find it and remove it. The search card is called, of course, a "Search for Weapon of M*A*S Destruction" card. Cute.

The search mechanics are interesting. Players play to win battles and gain Respect Points. When you find Weapons of M*A*S Destruction, you might gain respect (depending on which search card you have). When you don't find Weapons of M*A*S Destruction (depending on the card) you could "lose all your Respect." (ok, no more puns).

Players take turns attacking, choosing between 3 types of attacks. Each card has a "weak spot" on it. During one phase of the game players try to name the weak spot of opponent's M*A*S -- If they do it is destroyed. (These "shots" at opponent's cards are called "long shots"). Battles are usually "2 on 2" with extra "destroy" and "search" cards. Cards are awarded to each player based on rules, mostly "who won the attack?"

There is a Draw Phase, a "Deploy & Destroy phase" a "Long Shot" Phase, and an
"Attack" Phase. After the Draw Phase, each of the 3 remaing phases provides
interesting and different types of action. (See 'more info' below).

2 to 6 players, best with 2 to 5 singles or teams of 2 or 3. 64 cards + instructions.
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Trigos imin
description:
The game is made of 36 wooden cubes in four colors. There is no board: the cubes move on the playing surface, and the space changes as the game goes on.

The rules propose two different games :

IMIN is a movement game in which you must eliminate the cubes of your opponents on an horizontal ever changing 2D surface.

ASH is a 3D game: in the first phase you must try to form a square of four cube horizontally or vertically; if no one wins, then in the second phase you must eliminate the highest number of your opponents' cubes.

name: Sam & Max On The Road
description: A very silly board game published in addition to the Sam & Max Freelance Police Special #1

name: The Battle of Sharpsburg
description:
This is a tactical simulation of the American Civil War battle near Sharpsburg on 17 September 1862. The components include:
1 8x10 map
1 set of rules 2.5 pages long including charts & tables
1 set of 26 counters; 10 Union, 15 Confederate & 1 game turn

The Union Infantry are Corps-sized, the Confederate Infantry are Division-sized. No scale is given for distance on the map or for each (of the 10) turns. Mechanics are a simple yugo-igo, but rough terrain and ample artillery make things interesting.

Original images are provided, as well as some graphically-updated images.

This is a good example of what early DTP-like self-publishing could do. Remember ... 1975 ... 33 years ago.
categories: American Civil War, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Star Strike Vessel Compendium #1: Adventurer Class
description:
This is an expansion for the board game Space Master: Star Strike and Space Master: The Role Playing Game. It includes stats for 29 different space vessels like survey/exploration vessels, freighters, shuttles, yachts, privateers, scouts, slavers, blockade runners and couriers. Also included are 2 adventures for Space Master: The Role Playing Game and 65 full-color counters.

This expansion was produced in 1989 by Iron Crown Enterprises.

Expands:

Space Master: Star Strike
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Pettersson und Findus: Auf Entdeckungstour
description: Auf Entdeckungstour is a movement & memory game for children Ages 5 and up A player draws a hidden card with one of the 18 different images on the wooden board. The opponents try to lock up the correct image on the board while moving the Findus figure for a number of fields after each other. After a move, the card owner tells the next player the right direction to the correct image.

name: Eendenrally
