mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Chronopia: Dwarf Talon Gate
description:
A 3d Expansion Set for Chronopia

From the back of the box:

The greatest achievement of the Dwarves is also their best-kept secret. Beneath the world of day and night lies a dark world of twisting pathways and unknown terrors - the labyrinth of the Dwarves. Guarding the entrances to this underworld are the mighty Talon Gates. Fortified gateways raised by Dwarven skill in the likeness of the clan's totem, they are built to withstand the most determined onslaught and charged with their defense are the Talon Lords. Dwarves of iron will, sworn to die before any should pass beyond the gates they guard.

This box-set contains:
•An impressive full-color model, for you to construct from 16 A4 sheets of card.
• Two exclusive new Chronopia miniatures - The Dwarven Gatekeeper known as the Talon Lord and the powerful Stygian Hammerhead.
• A 32-page booklet with comprehensive new rules for fighting in and around buildings and structures, and for fighting underground. Also includes new templates and counters.
• A scenario set around a Talon Gate in the Land of the Two Rivers with exciting background text to bring the whole thing to life.

Note: This is not a stand-alone product; a copy of the main Chronopia rules and the Land of Two Rivers supplement are required to use this box set.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Leningrad Pack
description:
16 Scenarios compatible with the ASL system.

FE 62 Uncle Joe's Fury, July 1941: An old fashioned combined arms assault on boards 48 and 44 with a good sized Russian infantry and tank force attempting to capture buildings and kill Germans who are equipped with infantry, tanks and guns.

FE 63 Out Land, August 1941: The Finns and the Russians go at it in this scenario. Finnish infantry assaults the board 10 and 42 villages attempting to capture buildings against infantry, guns and tanks.

FE 64 The Iron Ring is Closed, August 1941: This is a very meaty scenario. 44 German squads, OBA, halftracks and assault guns attack on boards 40, 49, 42, 24, 22 and 23. The Russians defend with 42 squads and several guns. The victory conditions are interesting with each side attempting to control the riverbank.

FE 65 Straight to the Front, September 1941: This scenario offers some good replay value. The Germans attack across boards 19 and 11 attempting to capture some buildings. The Germans get SS infantry and some AFV. The Russians start with some infantry and receive random tank support. A medium sized scenario should be popular.

FE 66 Tedium, October 1941: This is a classic slogging match across boards 19 and 44. Dug-In Russian troops try to stop a combined arms German force. The Germans have infantry, tanks and halftracks against the Russians with infantry, fortifications and Guns.

FE 67 A Cold Day in Hell, December 1941: The Finns and the Russians go at it in this small infantry only action. The action takes place in winter conditions on boards 8 and 42. This should make for good tourney action.

FE 68 Beast of Prey, March 1942: A real and true slugfest in the woods. Once again dug-in Russian defenders on boards 32 and 36 try to hold Germans from exiting the board. The Russians get infantry, fortifications and Guns while the Germans get SS infantry and some Stugs.

FE 69 Tiger Woods, August 1942: Yes! Another scenario with Tiger in its title!!! If that is not enough to get you excited then this scenario's OB should do it. The Germans get 4 Tigers up against a couple of Russian T-43's and a AA Truck. Each side gets a good number of infantry. This action takes place on boards 36 and 42.

FE 70 Worker's Settlement No. 8, September 1942: This cool infantry only scenario (well the Germans get one INF gun) takes place on board 33 and 4. This scenario has a cool twist for entry conditions with the Russians entering anywhere on 3 board edges. A cool twist in the VC makes for some uncertainty on where to attack. Sure to be a favorite for the tourney crowd.

FE 71 Cold Steel Rain, January 1943: This is another meaty scenario that should offer some good replay value given the variable VC. The Germans get infantry and some AT Guns and defend on boards 33 and 48 against attacking Russian infantry, OBA and some T-60 tanks. .

FE 72 Manos a la Manos, February 1943: The Spanish Blue Division makes its debut in this action on boards 13 and 18. The Spanish infantry with an AT Gun and some variable additional forces must defend some terrain against a lot of Russian infantry, tanks and Flamethrower tanks. The Russians got the numbers but do they have the time to capture the victory terrain?!

FE 73 Polar Star, February 1943: Another meaty old-fashioned scenario, this time on boards 17, 19 and 18. The Germans get 24 squads, fortifications, Stugs and some AT Guns and must hold off a swarm of 32 Russian squads, Assault guns and tanks from exiting and capturing some buildings. Lots of options in this one fore each side.

FE 74 Fruitless Fighting, March 1943: The classic capture the village type scenario on boards 12 and 17. This scenario features 20 Russian squads supported by tanks and assault guns attacking the village against an outpost of SS infantry and some fortifications. The Germans receive reinforcements in the form of infantry and 4 Tiger tanks.

FE 75 Porech'e Push, August 1943: My favorite of the scenarios in this pack. The Russians fight out of a bridgehead against a strong German force to capture the hills overlooking their bridgehead. Really get the flavor of the historic action in this one. The Russians get a bunch of infantry and an assortment of AFV against German infantry, guns and additional forces that they select from an available force pool. This scenario is set on boards 3, 8 and 49.

FE 76 The Battle of Krasnogvadeisk, January 1944: This is another one of those big scenarios that capture the flavor of east front action. Set on boards 18, 49 and 22 this is a meaty scenario with 26 Russian squads and 5 AFV attacking to capture some buildings against 21 squads, 4 tanks and some fortifications.

FE 77 Stalin's Revenge, June 1944: Another Finnish versus Russian scenario setup on boards 5 and 32. This is a smallish scenario featuring 9 Finnish squads and a couple of AT Guns against 15 Russian squads and 3 AFV. This is a brutal one for the Finnish as they attempt to stop the Russians from capturing some buildings.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation

name: Das Kopflose Dinner: Die Verlobungsfeier
description:
"Die Verlobunsgfeier" (= "the espousal") is the dawn of this medieval trilogie around the intrigue of the family "Gräfingen". "Theodor von Gräfingen" (lord of the castle Gräfingen) invites his guests for the engagement of his daughter "Heidelinde von Gräfingen" and the young and prosperous "Brechtwein von Schweinsbergen". Yet nothing is like it seems.
A mysterious crime happend and some twists in the storyline adding zest to this case.

Gameplay:
Just invite your guests and host your own murder mystery dinner. Everybody gets a roledescription and after the game started more and more hints to the murderer.

Goal:
Mainly you have to find the murderer, but also everybody has his own interests and private goals. So for example the second born would be interested to blame his older brother and let him get arrested and punished, so that he can get the heritage.

name: Matspelet
description:
A Swedish quiz game about food. Contains 350 questions in 6 categories ("Food of the world", "Ingredients", "Food tradition", "Kitchen knowledge", "Smorgasbord" & "Guess right").

The player in turn roll a die to choose which category to answer a question from. The winner is the player who has the most points when all cards have been used once.

name: Exchange Explosion Evaporation Experiment Expansion
description:
E5 = Exchange Explosion Evaporation Experiment Expansion is a new Expansion for your game of Experiment and introduces some new game elements and gives the possibility to add more danger to the game.

3 super-wildcards are now available but they come with a price.

Extra danger with an extra explosion and 2 broken bottles.

The black pawn and evaporation rules will give an extra boost to 1-point tasks if you complete them at the right moment.
Will you use the power to block your opponents or will you try to give yourself an advantage (and will your opponents allow this or will they try to block your advantage in return)?

New exciting options and new tactical decisions for Experiment

name: Arkham Horror: Penny Arcade Characters
description:
From Penny Arcade comes the fabled Investigator Johnathan "Gabe" Gabriel, Investigator Tycho Erasmus Brahe, and Guardian Anne-Claire. These are official expansions from Fantasy Flight Games to be used with games of "Arkham Horror".

Investigator Johnathan "Gabe" Gabriel

Rules Summary :

Home -- River Docks
4 Sanity
6 Stamina
2 Focus

Fixed Possessions : $6
Random Possessions : 2 Common Items, 1 Unique Item, 1 Skill

Fists of Fury : Any Phase -- Gabe gains a +2 bonus to Combat Checks.

Fists of Rage : If the Doom Track is within 3 spaces of awakening the Ancient One, Gabe automatically passes all Will checks.

Never Again : Tycho no longer allows Gabe to use any Weapons.

Speed -- 1 2 3 4
Sneak -- 4 3 2 1
Fight -- 4 5 6 7
Will -- 4 3 2 1
Lore -- 0 1 2 3
Luck -- 3 2 1 0

Investigator Tycho Erasmus Brahe

Rules Summary :

Home -- The Library
6 Sanity
4 Stamina
2 Focus

Fixed Possessions : $5, 1 Common Item (Tommy Gun), 1 Unique Item (The King in Yellow)
Random Possessions : 2 Unique Items, 1 Skill

Multi-Tasker : Any Phase -- Tycho reduces all movement costs on Tomes to 0.

Rational Man : Any Phase -- Tycho may spend 1 Clue token instead of losing 1 Sanity or 1 Stamina. He may do this as often as he likes but may not use this ability during the Final Battle.

Speed -- 1 2 3 4
Sneak -- 4 3 2 1
Fight -- 0 1 2 3
Will -- 5 4 3 2
Lore -- 2 3 4 5
Luck -- 3 2 1 0

Guardian Anne-Claire

Mechanical Genius : Investigators may always use the location ability of the Administration Building, regardless of other effects.

Cruel Taskmistress : Investigators receive a $1 discount when using the Administration Building's location ability for each Weapon or monster trophy they discard.

To the Rescue : Once per game, after an investigator has made a Combat check, the players may choose to have Anne-Claire show up to help out with her flamethrower. She adds 3 successes to the result of the Combat check.
categories: Adventure, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Horror, Novel-based, Science Fiction, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Point to Point Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: O Tannen-BOOM!
description:
O Tannen-BOOM! is an explosively fun card game for 2-4 players.

Players seek to Build and decorate their own Christmas Tree while blowing the branches off of their opponent's! Best tree (or what is left of one) will go home with the prize!

On a player's turn they may draw cards, play cards (branches of your tree) or play Baubles/Bombs. Players score points for sets of similar Baubles in a row. Many cards also have additional actions that may be played upon adding them to your tree.

Bauble tokens are also your Bomb tokens so you must choose carefully whether to use them in decorating your tree (to gain points) or in blowing up your opponent's (to prevent them from doing the same).

This game was submitted as part of the 2010 Christmas PNP Game Design Contest.

name: Poor Knight
description:
The Poor Knight is an educational card game that develops observance, planning and counting skills. Players learn to recognise geometrical forms, colors and their relationships and use the acquired skills in the game.

The game consists of four tournament rounds. During the first tournament there is one battle, in the second tournament two battles and so on. In total there are 1+2+3+4=10 battles from which players are trying to gather as many points as possible.

The gameplay is based around knight cards and battle cards. The battle cards give 1-2 pieces of information, for example heraldic animal and color. They're also worth points. The knight cards each have some info that corresponds to a number of battle cards. During a battle a battle card is first turned face up. Players can then participate in the battle with any knight cards that have any matching information to the battle card. These are played by a blind bidding mechanism. There are also some force cards that add to the total power of your knight cards. The player that plays the highest total power of knight cards wins the battle and claims the battle card. Only after the end of the tournament the players get to replenish their hands with new cards.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Medieval

name: Direct Hit
description: A target game where bombs are loaded into a bomber and then dropped over a board in an attempt to hit the targets. The game comes with a wood bomber and 4 plastic "bombs" with metal points on the tips of the bombs (similar to tips of darts). A color lithograph board depicts topographical "targets" with various point values assigned to them. Each player takes turns dropping their load of bombs on the board and scores points based on what targets they hit. The game is not dated, but it may be post-WWII, perhaps in the 1950's.

name: Kleine Helden promo card "Dämonenschwert"
description:
Promo weapon card for the card game "Kleine Helden" given out for free at the SPIEL 2010 in Essen.

Dämonenschwert means Demon Sword.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting

name: A Fistful of Tripods
description:
A Fistful of Tripods is a set of miniatures war game rules that cover the Marian invasion described by H. G. Wells in his novel "War of the Worlds".

Players can re-create the first "historical" Martian invasion of 1890's (which was an all out rout of the humans), or play one of several alternate scenarios from the 1920's through the 1990's.

The rules are based on the Fistful of TOWS miniatures rule set.

This description is paraphrased from the introductory section of the rulebook.

name: Colombo
description:
Players are sailors who try to reach America before the other players, starting from Europe and crossing Atlantic ocean. During the perilious travel they'll have to avoid storms, mutinies, hull crashes, winds, also thanks to Colombo's cards' help.

In order to achieve their objective they'll have to draw and play the right cards and to move their ships the fastest way possible to reach the american coasts.
mechanics: Action Points, Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement

name: Friesematenten: Volle Vierzig
description:
German Expansion card to Friesematenten from Amigo, available at Essen 2010.

German Text:
"Spiel die Karte gegen einen Mitspieler deiner Wahl. Du erhälst von ihm €40. Hat er keine €40, bekommst Du all sein Geld. Er erhält dafür die Karte und kann sie ab der nächsten Runde einsetzen."

"Play the card against a player of your choice. You get €40 from him. If he has less than €40, you get all of his money. He gets this card and can sit out of the next round"

The illustration shows the designer, Friedemann Friese.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Income, Layering, Race, Take That, Turn Order: Auction

name: The Society for Stacking Things on Top of Other Things
description:
Publisher Blurb: The Society for Stacking Things on Top of Other Things is a small, fast-playing deck building game for 2-4 players.

Players will build a deck by drafting cards from a communal pool. These cards consist of Action cards and Thing cards.

Players take it in turn to play actions which affect how many cards can be drafted into their deck during their turn. After doing so, they may place a thing card on their personal stack. Once this is done there is a cleanup phase. During this phase players replenish their hands to ready themselves for the next turn.
Players attempt to create the biggest stack of Things. Each Thing is worth points. The first player to 1000+ points whom is able to place the Winner Flag on top of his stack is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Print & Play
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Dust: A post-apocalyptic role-playing boardgame
description:
Dust is a real-time post nuclear role-playing game without a gamemaster. Each player creates an unique character with different abilities und items.
The mission book shows the setup of the scenario and the time until the mission failed (1-4 days, 24 minutes playtime per day).

Each player uses sandtimers to determinate the action he'll use. Every opponent has a small sheet with his abilities and actions he'll do, if a player interacts with the NPC.
The players have to suceed the main mission, but can always accept secondary missions to get extra experience and items or money.
categories: Collectible Components, Fighting, Science Fiction, Travel
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Role Playing, Simultaneous Action Selection, Storytelling

name: Les Acrobates
description:
Each player gets a set of acrobats (1 through 5). The objective is to stack the acrobats one on top of the other (from 1 to 5).

Throwing the die; the highest throw starts. Each player throws the die until they get a 1, then a 2 and so on to stack the 5 acrobats. A player who throws a 6 loses a turn. If the stack of acrobats falls, the player will have to start again from 1. (source from the directions on the box)

name: Walking Dots
description: This game is played on a 8x8 square board. To begin, each player drops two friendly stones on empty cells. On each turn, each player either drops a friendly stone on an empty cell orthogonally adjacent to another friendly stone, or passes. When both players pass, the player with more stones on the board wins.

name: Artificers
description:
Overview:
Players are skilled artificers trying to purchase the best components to make the most deadly gladiator weapon the world has ever seen. The game takes place in two rounds. In the first round the players compete in a shrewd auction to get the components they need. In the second round, the players build their weapons and battle to decide the winner.

Components:
1 pack of A-Type Nestoriles (60 tiles in 10 colors)

name: Corre que te pillo
description:
Cats and Mice run around the board in a crazy race to save their skins (box text).

Funny game in which each player must move his mice to the finish line, while at the same time tries to get the more the better of the other players mice.
The winner is the player with most points at the end of the game (from the game rules).

Gatos y ratones corren por el tablero en una loca carrera para salvar el pellejo (box text)

Juego muy divertido en que cada jugador debe avanzar sus ratones hasta la meta, mientras intenta comer el máximo de ratones de los otros jugadores.
El ganador es quién consigue más puntos al finalizar el juego.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Islands Go Go Go
description: The Game uses the map of Hong Kong Islands District as the background. Players discover the scenic spots of Hong Kong of Islands District and collect scoring points by using transportation card(s) according to the transportation type and number stated on the route. For example, the player uses 4 "Ferry" cards, the corresponding player marker on the map will move from Central to Cheung Chau and collect scoring card or bonus card on Cheung Chau. Each turn player either draw transportation card(s) or move the player marker around the map to score. A collection of location cards will also provide bonus points at the end of the game. The player with the highest score wins the game.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Dragon Blast: Battlestorm
description:
Dragon Blast is a Super Powered, Martial Arts Combat Card Game AND Board Game! In this hybrid game, the players battle to see who will be the last one standing. You must use your cards strategically to attack and defend against the other players as well as move your character around a tactical game board. Battle to knock out your opponents while powering yourself up to unleash incredible, legendary attacks!

But you must beware, there are other incredible warriors with other super-powered attacks! You can play as one of six legendary combatants each with their own powers and style of fighting.

To be successful you must learn to use and master a variety of attacks and defenses! Punch, Kick, Block, Dodge and Blast your way to victory!

You can play this game in a two player duel or up to four players in a free-for-all brawl! Don’t like to be alone? Team up with a partner and play two versus two teams!

Choose from two different Battlefields to wage your destruction on!
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Team-Based Game, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers
publishers: Nightstalker Games, The Game Crafter, LLC

name: Trivial Pursuit: 1997 Edition
description:
This edition of the TRIVIAL PURSUIT Year in Review Series contains questions about the highlights of the year 1997. As with other Trivial Pursuit games, players roll dice to travel around the board, answering questions in the category indicated by the space upon which they land. Players seek to get pie pieces by landing on key spaces for each of the six categories before traveling to the middle to of the board for a final question to win the game.

Contains:
250 cards (with 1500 questions)
1 cad holder
1 dice (colored)
24 scoring wedges
4 player tokens

name: Agoraphobia
description: In Agoraphobia, players try to keep their pieces (agoraphobes) out of the crowd. Agoraphobia is an abstract strategy game for two players in which each player seeks to push their opponents pieces into large groups. Each turn, a player places one agoraphobe on a hexagonal grid. When it is places, each agoraphobe pushes all adjacent pieces away by either one or two spaces, depending on the size of the piece that was played. An agoraphobe may only be placed if it pushes at least one piece away, leaving it sufficient breathing room. The game ends when one player can not place any of their remaining pieces. The player who ends the game with the largest group of adjacent pieces is the loser.

name: Zaragoza 1710: Juego de Cartas de Estrategia
description:
The background of "Zaragoza 1710. Juego de Cartas de Estrategia" (Saragossa 1710. Strategy Card Game) is the Spanish Succession War, facing the french-spanish Bourbon forces against the Habsburg's alliance to take the throne of the Spanish Empire. This two players game evokes the battle fought at the gates of Saragossa the 20th August 1710. In this battle were present the two candidates to the Spanish Crown: Phillip, Duke of Anjou, and Charles, Archiduke of Austria. The players must manage these and other leaders, command the troops and use the appropiate tactics to break the morale of the opposing army and force it to leave the battlefield.
Each player begins the game with 10 morale points. There are 76 cards divided in four categories: leaders, troops, tactics and terrain. Before the match, the players lay down the terrain cards as "board" to deploy the leader and troop cards. After, they launch his ranks against the oponent trying to reduce his morale points to zero and using the tactic cards to influence the results of the clash of arms...

"Zaragoza 1710. Juego de Cartas de Estrategia" está ambientado en la Guerra de Sucesión Española, que enfrentaría las fuerzas franco-españolas de los Borbones contra la alianza de los Habsburgo por la consecución del trono del imperio español. Este juego para dos personas evoca la batalla que tuvo lugar a las puertas de la ciudad de Zaragoza el 20 de Agosto de 1710. En esa batalla estuvieron presentes los dos candidatos a la corona española: Felipe, Duque de Anjou, y Carlos, Archiduque de Austria. Los jugadores deben utilizar a éstos y otros líderes, comandar las tropas y usar las tácticas adecuadas para romper la moral del ejército contrario y obligarlo así a abandonar el campo de batalla.
Cada jugador comienza la partida con 10 puntos de moral. Hay 76 cartas, divididas en cuatro categorías: líderes, tropas, tácticas y terreno. Antes de comenzar, los jugadores colocan las cartas de terreno a modo de tablero en el que desplegar las cartas de líder y de tropa. Después, cada uno lanza sus filas contra las de su oponente intentando reducir a cero sus puntos de moral y utilizando las cartas de táctica para influir en el resultado del choque de las armas...
categories: Card Game, Educational, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Algorilude
description:
Algorilude is a french card game by Louis Abraham.
The game consists of a deck of cards symbolizing various mathematical operations beneficial or harmful.
The goal is to construct an algorithm representing the process of a calculator (operations, loops, ...).
Playing his best cards, each player will try to reach the highest score while slowing down opponents with bad loops, divisions...
It's a logical card game with little chance.
categories: Card Game, Educational, Math, Number, Puzzle
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Open Drafting

name: Lórum
description:
Hungarian card game played with a traditional Hungarian deck of cards (standard deck without the cards 2-6, which uses German suits). At first players bid for being the starting player.

From wikipedia (edited) :

Lorum consists of 8 or 6 different individual games or contracts each with its own aim and rules. Each game is played four times making a total of 32/24 games in a session. The winner of a trick leads to the next. Suit must be followed; if that is not possible, any card may be discarded. The trick is taken by the highest card of the led suit and there are no trumps.

The composition of the eight/six contracts varies, but always comprises the following four deals:

No Hearts. In No Hearts, also called Reds, the aim is to avoid winning Hearts or "reds". A red may not be led to the first trick unless forehand only has reds. Players may not discard a red to the first trick unless they only have reds. In the succeeding tricks, reds may be discarded if a player has no card of the led suit. Each red card taken in tricks scores 1 point.
Obers. The aim is in Obers to avoid capturing Obers. Each Ober is worth 2 points. An Ober may not be led to the first trick, nor may an Ober be laid to it unless the player only has an Ober in the led suit (i.e. the Ober is a singleton). In the remaining tricks, Obers may be discarded at any stage if a player cannot follow suit.
No Tricks. In No Tricks, also just Tricks, the aim is to avoid taking any tricks. Each trick is worth a point.
Lorum. This contract is, like the last deal in most compendium games, a Domino-type contract. Forehand leads any card to the table. The next player in turn must play either a card of the same rank in another suit or lay off the next highest card of the same suit next to the first card. An Ace follows a Seven. If a player is unable to play a card, he misses a turn. Players may not miss a turn if they are able to play. Every turn missed costs one point. As soon as the first player goes out by laying off his last card, the remaining players score a point for each card still held in the hand. Alternatively the deal can continue until each player in succession goes out. In this variation, the second player to go out scores 1 point per card, the third player, 2 points per card and the last player, 3 points per card.

In addition, one or more (typically two or four) of the following contracts are usually inserted between the third deal above (No Tricks) and the final deal (Lorum).[6]

First and Last Trick. In First and Last (Erster und letzter Stich) the aim is to avoid taking the first and last tricks; each of which counts as 4 (variation: 5) points. Short variant: Only two cards are dealt to each player, the stock being given to the next dealer. The first player to lead plays one of his two cards. The winner of the trick then leads to the 'last' trick. Suit must be followed if possible. Each trick scores 4 (or 5) points.
Fifth Trick. In Fifth Trick (Fünfter Stich) players must avoid taking the fifth trick, after which the deal is ended. It scores 8 points.
Seventh Trick. As Fifth Trick except players avoid taking the seventh trick.
Red King. The aim in Red King, also called Red King-less, is to avoid capturing the 'red king' (the King of Hearts). It scores: 16 points when captured in the first trick, 8 points in the second to seventh tricks, 32 points in the last trick and 64 points if announced before playing the last trick.
Hairy Ape. As Red King, but players hold their cards facing their opponents; then play cards at random. If two or more are of the same suit, the highest wins otherwise each card 'takes' itself. The player who take the red King scores 8 points.
Train (Vonat). Using the Ace-Ten scoring system, card points are added cumulatively as they are played. The first to exceed 25 wins 1 point, 50 wins 2 points, 75 wins 3 points and 100 wins 4 points.
Quart(el) or Kvart. In Quartel, to the first card played, the 3 next higher cards of the same suit must be added in sequence by whoever has them until and unless no-one has the next higher card. Players do not need to play in clockwise order. The trick is won by the player who placed the last card in the sequence and he then leads to the next trick. If an eligible player has a highest card of its suit at that stage of the game in his hand (usually an Ace, but also a Seven if the Eight of the same suit has already been played), he can put it away as "high". The game ends when the first player goes out by discarding his last card. This may not necessarily be the current player. The cards remaining in the other players' hands score 1 point each.
All Bad (Mindenrossz). A combination of several contracts e.g. No Tricks, No Hearts, No Obers and No Red King.

name: ScatterLand
description:
ScatterLand is a game of strategy and deduction for 2-4 players. It takes roughly 30 minutes to play.

The basic idea is that players are exploring an archipelago in search of islands. The game board consists of a 9×9 array of 81 squares, further divided into nine 3×3 boxes. There are 18 islands total, but these islands aren’t distributed randomly; instead, they are arranged so that two islands occupy each 3×3 box, each row, and each column. What's more, these islands are initially hidden from view.

Players claim one square per turn. A player either places an island of her color in the region (if there's an island there) or a boat of her color in the region (if there isn't). Players are trying first to discover and then to connect together as many islands as they can: the more islands they connect together, the more points they receive at the end of the game.

Players use logic to determine where the islands are likely to be, but logic alone is not enough: players must also think tactically and strategically in order both to foster their own growth and limit the growth of their opponents.

ScatterLand takes no more than five minutes to learn (or to teach), but its gameplay is surprisingly deep. There are a lot of things to try to balance when deciding where to play: do you want to claim a new island as your own or try to connect two of your islands together? Do you want to try to consolidate your own position or be the first to explore a given area? Do you want to focus on expanding your chains or trying to cut off your opponents?

Two versions of the game are included: the basic version (described above) and the advanced version (which limits the number of exclusive islands any one player can claim).

ScatterLand can be found at http://boardgameforge.wordpress.com/scatterland/ -- just click the links toward the bottom of the page for both the rules and 20 additional boards.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Exploration, Print & Play, Territory Building
mechanics: Enclosure, Network and Route Building, Pattern Recognition

name: Paris: Crime Investigation – Card Game
description:
"Paris: Crime Investigation" is a card game for 2 players whose theme is a criminal investigation, which seeks to identify a killer, through the administration of cards representing suspects, weapons, alibis and evidence.

Each player represents a French police investigator, who must gather as much evidence connecting each suspect to the murder, adding the maximum points possible.

The game mechanics are similar to Rummy, each player must make melds with evidence, weapons, suspects and alibis, trying to gain maximum points. In each round the player must discard one card and, if not using the strategy, this card can help your opponent to form melds and win more points.

The game also has a dose of luck, providing excitement to every round.

The game is Print & Play, and have 54 cards.
